simplenlg.lexicon
Class Lexicon

java.lang.Object
  simplenlg.lexicon.Lexicon
All Implemented Interfaces:
LexiconInterface
public class Lexicon
extends Object
implements LexiconInterface

This class implements the LexiconInterface, providing a number of additional methods which operate either directly on strings, or on LexicalItems. The Lexicon is therefore both a repository of lexical information, and the source from which a finite set of morphological rules can be applied to strings.

The Lexicon comes pre-loaded with a few simplenlg.exception lists, expecially for verbs which either take no affixation in any form, or have suppletive forms, or take consonant doubling. It also loads a small set of symbols. For all other exceptions to the morphological rules defined here, it relies on the predefined pattern-action rules in the package simplenlg.lexicon.lexicalrules.rulesets.

A Lexicon contains separate stores for the four classes that inherit from ContentWord, namely: Verbs, Nouns, Adjectives and Symbols. The function words defined in this package, namely Determiner and Pronoun, are not stored directly, as these are constants. The Lexicon has access to these items, however.

Author:
albert gatt

Field Detail

NULL_VERB

public static final Verb NULL_VERB
Constructor Detail

Lexicon

public Lexicon()
Creates a new instance of DefaultLexicon. The constructor initialises four maps, verbs, nouns, adjectives and symbols, which store ContentWords. It also loads a list of verb exceptions and symbols at construction time. These are found in VerbLists and SymbolLists.

populateFromFile

public void populateFromFile(String filename,
                             String fieldSeparator)
                      throws IOException
Populates the DefaultLexicon with items from a file. Files MUST be in the format "word fieldsep category", where fieldsep is a field-separator (comma, space, tab or whatever), which is specified as an argument, category is one of "noun", "adj", "verb", "sym"

Note that this method can be called several times. Calling it multiple times causes the DefaultLexicon to add items, but none of the previously inserted items will be deleted.

Parameters:
filename - The path to the file.
fieldSeparator - The symbol separating words and categories in the file.
Throws:
IOException - if the file is not found.
IOException

populateFromDatabase

public void populateFromDatabase(Connection con,
                                 String table,
                                 String wordField,
                                 String categoryField)
                          throws SQLException
Retrieve lexical items from a database. The method expects three String arguments: a table name, the name of a word field, and the name of a category field. The word field should contain the lemma or string representation of the word; the category field should specify whether it's a noun, verb or adjective.

Example: Suppose you have a database "wordDB", containing table "myTable" which looks like this:

-------------------
| word | category |
-------------------
|dog | noun |
|cat | noun |
|run | verb |
------------------

You can load these into the simplenlg.lexicon using this method, giving it arguments "myTable", "word", "category".

Parameters:
con - A database connection handler. This should have already established a connection to the database successfully.
table - The table name.
wordField - The name of the field in table which contains words.
categoryField - The name of the field in table which contains grammatical category.
Throws:
an - SQLException if the execution of the SQL Statement fails.
SQLException

getPlural

public String getPlural(String word)
Gets the plural form of a word. In actual fact, the DefaultLexicon checks whether it already contains a Noun whose baseform is word. If that is the case, it returns the plural form by calling Noun.getPlural() from the Noun. If not, it creates a new instance of Noun, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, returning the plural form.

Parameters:
word - The baseform of some word that needs to be pluralised
Returns:
A String which is the plural of word

getComparative

public String getComparative(String word)
Gets the comparative form of an adjective. In actual fact, the DefaultLexicon checks whether it already contains a Adjective whose baseform is word. If that is the case, it returns the comparative form by calling Adjective.getComparative() from the Adjective. If not, it creates a new instance of Adjective, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, returning the comparative form.

Parameters:
word - - The baseform of some adjective
Returns:
A String which is the comparative form of word

If that is the case, it returns the superlative form by calling Adjective.getSuperlative() from the Adjective. If not, it creates a new instance of Adjective, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, returning the superlative form.

getPast

public String getPast(String word)
Gets the past tense form of a verb. Whenever called, DefaultLexicon checks whether it already contains a Verb whose baseform is word. If that is the case, it returns the past tense form by calling Verb.getPast() from the Verb. If not, it creates a new instance of Verb, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, and returns the past tense form form.

Parameters:
word - The baseform of some verb
Returns:
A String which is the past tense form of word

If not, it creates a new instance of Verb, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, and returns the past participle form.

public String getPresent3SG(String word)

If not, it creates a new instance of Verb, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, and returns the present tense form.

Returns:
A String which is the 3rd person singular present tense form of word

getPresentParticiple

public String getPresentParticiple(String word)

If that is the case, it returns the "ing" form by calling Verb.getPresentParticiple() from the Verb. If not, it creates a new instance of Verb, which gets stored in this instance of DefaultLexicon, and returns the "ing" form.

Parameters:

Returns:
A String which is the "ing" form of word

addRule

public void addRule(MorphologicalRule rule)
Add a morphological rule to this simplenlg.lexicon. The rule must implement the MorphologicalRule interface. This is the easiest way to add functionality to the DefaultLexicon. New MorphologicalRules added in this way are indexed by their name, the return value of the MorphologicalRule.getName() method.

Parameters:
rule - The MorphologicalRule to be added.
See Also:
MorphologicalRule

applyRule

public String applyRule(String ruleName,
                        String word)
Apply a MorphologicalRule with name ruleName to word word. The rule must already have been added to the DefaultLexicon. If no such rule exists, the return value is null.

Parameters:
ruleName - The name of the MorphologicalRule
word - The String to which the rule should be applied.
Returns:
The result of applying the rule.

applyRule

public String applyRule(String ruleName,
                        LexicalItem lex)
Apply a MorphologicalRule with name ruleName to LexicalItem lex. The rule must already have been added to the DefaultLexicon. If no such rule exists, the return value is null.

Parameters:
ruleName - The name of the MorphologicalRule
lex - The LexicalItem to which the rule should be applied.
Returns:
The result of applying the rule.

                          Person p,

t - The Tense
p - The Person
n - The Number combination
Returns:
A java.lang.String, the inflected form.

getBeSubjunctive

public String getBeSubjunctive()
Returns:
Utility method: The form of the verb "to be" used in subjunctive mood (conditionals), i.e. "were"
